lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
You will use this as a baseline for the individual project, as well as the team project later in the semester.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 11** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Duke.Duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Duke.Duke.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
Tommy is a task tracking application, run using Command Line Interface (CLI)
This application was built on Java 11. Ensure that you have Java 11 or above installed.
1. Download duke.jar file from this repository.
2. Copy the file into a folder. The task list will be saved into this folder.
3. Open terminal application and change directory to the above folder.
4. Run the jar file by entering `java -jar duke.jar` into the terminal.
You should be greeted with the following output:
What can I do for you?
5. Input one of the supported commands, and press the "Enter" key to execute.
6. Exit the application safely with the "bye" command.
The following commands are supported by Tommy.
Displays all tasks currently in your task list.
Here are the tasks in your list:
Adds a todo task to your task list.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 1 tasks in the list.
Adds a deadline task to your task list.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 2 tasks in the list.
Adds an event task to your task list
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 3 tasks in the list.
Mark a task in your list as done.
Nice! I've marked this task as done:
Mark a task in your list as not done.
OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:
Find all tasks in your task list with the specified keyword in their names.
Here are the matching tasks in your list:
Delete a task from your task list.
Now you have 2 tasks in the list.
Bye. Hope to see you again soon!
* Duke is a task tracking application using Command Line Interface.
* Initialises application and reads existing data from local file.
* Runs the application, taking in user input until "bye" command is issued.
* Error if description of Todo task is not given in user input
* Error if user command is not recognised
* Parser deals with making sense of the user input
* Determine type of command from user input
* @return Type of command to be executed
* Obtains description of task or command to be executed
* Determine if bye command is issued by user
* Storage deals with loading tasks from the file and saving tasks in the file.
* Saves the given task list to a specified local file
* @param filePath Location of file for task list to be saved to
* @param list Task list to be saved
public static void writeToFile(String filePath, ArrayList<Task> list) {
* Loads task list saved in specified local file to the task list
* @param filePath Location of file with the saved list
* @param list Target ArrayList to load task list
* @throws FileNotFoundException Error if file is not found in the specified location
public static void getFileContents(String filePath, ArrayList<Task> list) throws FileNotFoundException {
* TaskList contains the task list and handles all operations relating to the list
* Check if a task has been marked as done
* @param isDone Marker signifying if task is done or not
public static void checkMarked (Task task, String isDone) {
* Converts the index of the task from String to Integer
* @param commandActual String containing index of task
* @return Index of task as an integer
* Prints out all tasks currently stored in the list

System.out.println(" Now you have " + list.size() + " tasks in the list.");

* Modifies the task list according to the user command given
* @param commandType Type of command to be executed
* @param commandActual Description and deadline of command, if any
* @param fileLocation Path of local file to store command
* @throws IllegalCommand Error if unsupported command is issued
public void executeTask (String commandType, String commandActual, String fileLocation) throws IllegalCommand {
* The Ui class deals with interactions with the users, including reading of inputs and displaying various outputs.
* Prints a line to separate outputs
* Greets the user with welcome message
System.out.println(" Hello! I'm\n" + tommyLogo + "\n What can I do for you?");
System.out.println(" Bye. Hope to see you again soon!\n");
* Reads user input from command line and returns it
System.out.println(" OOPS!!! I'm sorry, but I don't know what that means :-(");
System.out.println(" OOPS!!! The description of a todo cannot be empty.");
System.out.println(" OOPS!!! I'm sorry, but I don't know what that means :-(");
System.out.println(" OOPS!!! I'm sorry, but I was unable to write to the file :-(");
System.out.println(" OOPS!!! The given task number does not exist!");
* Deadline tasks are tasks that need to be done before a specific date/time
* @param by Deadline for task to be done by
* Format the task as a String to display as output
* Event tasks are tasks that start at a specific time and ends at a specific time.
* Format the task as a String to display as output
* Task is an abstract class for tasks.
* Formats the status of task to display as output
return (isDone ? "X" : " "); // mark done Duke.task with X
* Format the task as a String to display as output
* Todo tasks are basic tasks without any date/time attached to it.
* Format the task as a String to display as output
